Q: isn't this massively deflationary?

A: Yes!

A balance sheet recession emerges after the bursting of a
nationwide asset price bubble that leaves a large number of
private-sector balance sheets with more liabilities than assets.

In order to repair their balance sheets, private sector moves away from profit maximization to debt minimization. With the private sector de-leveraging, even at zero interest rates, newly generated savings and debt repayments enter the banking system but cannot leave the system due to the lack of borrowers. The sum of savings and debt repayments end up becoming the leakage to the income stream.

The deflationary gap created by the above leakage will continue to push the economy toward a contractionary equilibrium until the private sector is too impoverished to save any money(=depression).

In this type of recession, the economy will not enter self-
sustaining growth until private sector balance sheets are repaired.

Closing off-shore tax havens was part of the the End OffShoring Act that was shut down by the G.O.P.

Merck & Co. brought home over $9 billion to finance its acquisition of Schering-Plough Corp tax free. Pfizer inc. repatriated $30billion in its acquisition of Wyeth.

The profits are subject to the normal tax rate, nominally 35% but the effective tax rate is much lower and sometimes non-existent.

This is a sad but true story. Do not read this if you cry easily. 38A reminded me of this and now the only way I can shed my grief is to share it. We once owned a home in Connecticut with a pond in the rear.  The house had a deck in the rear facing the pond.  One spring a new family of Mallard ducks came to our pond.  As the mother was swimming around the pond with her ducklings, one got pulled under.  Alas, the duckling had been attacked by the resident snapping turtle which had bitten off the duckling’s foot.  He survived. He would spend the evenings under a small tree along the pond while the rest of the family went to a more secure nest for the night. He grew up, despite the dangers of the raccoons and foxes that lurked in the surrounding forest. We named the footless duck Peggy, short for Pegleg. Peggy grew into an adult and took Gwendolyn as his bride. They made a cute couple. They would even come onto the deck for their cracked corn and even feed out of our hands. Peggy and Gwendolyn had a family of their own. They would arrive to our pond in the morning and spend the day but return to their nest across the road. Sadly, one evening as they were crossing the highway Gwendolyn, protecting her young, unsuccessfully fended off an oncoming car. Peggy continued raising the family without Gwendolyn. One does not think of a duck as road kill. I still don’t think of Gwendolyn in that light. But, such is the way of nature. If the snapping turtle doesn’t get you, man will.

To quote: "Why should a law abiding citizen, who has never comitted a crime, and never would in his (or her) wildest dreams, be sanctioned for the act of lunatics and criminals?"

So, Martin of Nebraska, I ask just this question: how, precisely, are we to distinguish that law-abiding citizen from the citizen who would commit crimes, or become a lunatic criminal?

Prior to their having done committed a crime, all criminals were "law-abiding citizens", you know.

As for the argument that we don't know who will go crazy, therefore we should assume everyone will go crazy, so it then follows that no one should be allowed to have an assault weapon, I ask:

What happened to the presumption of innocence? Pre-emptive measures against a segment of society, the vast majority of which have never committed a crime? Really?

I absolutly agree that the mentally unstable, criminals, domestic abusers, and the incompetent shouldn't have access to firearms, but to expand that to those who have not committed a crime, just because of what you are scared they might do???

It seems that you are willing to give up a significant right, as long as you are the ones who are not giving anything up.

And you people call the gun owners nuts . . . How ironic.

what a tired argument. The gun nuts start with "why should law abiding blah blah etc. WE DON'T WANT YOUR HUNTING AND LEGAL GUNS!!! We want your automatic weapons and huge ammo clips. We want control of every gun transaction in the country. We want insane and violent people not to have guns. Can we do that perfectly? No, but what we are doing is nuts!!!

Mr. Cavett, the great concern that gun owners have at this stage is that the government will unjustly ban the firearms that they legally own. Why should a law abiding citizen, who has never comitted a crime, and never would in his (or her) wildest dreams, be sanctioned for the act of lunatics and criminals?

It's ironic. With only 323 deaths by a rifle, of any type, in 2011, the knee-jerk reaction to ban "assault weapons" and "high capacity magazines", while truly predictable, is completely ineffective. You have a better chance at winning the lottery than being a victim of a rifle shooting. And you think the gun owners are the ones who are scared .

Universal background checks? Sure, make it happen. But recognize that they are completely ineffective in stopping crime. There are millions of firearms in circulation, unlocated, untracked. If two criminals are determined to commit a crime in secret, specifically the transfer of a weapon without a background check, there is no law that will stop them. Don't believe me? Look at how well our laws work preventing the sale of illegal drugs . . .

Gun confiscation? A complete pipe-dream. Who would actually do the confiscation? Law enforcement? Not likely. Many of the law enforcement personnel are strongly pro-second amendment. The National Guard and/or military? Agan, it will never happen. Remember, they took an oath to "defend the Constitution of the United States, against all enemies, foreign and domestic."

So we should treat all children as if they need to score as well as future doctors or olympians or be relegated to second class educational status --and resources--for the rest of their lives?  How on earth did we manage to get  brilliant doctors and musicians before such high-pressure  testing?

I have to agree with you completely.

So far, those who complain against (or manage to go away with) standardised tests and other objective (yes, objective) selection tools have precious little to show us to serve as a replacement, especially when the ultimate outcome comparison is concerned.

But political correctness is - I can attest from personal experience - even more effective tool to silence reason or opposing view than communist censorship typically was. Therefore, we will have more push to go away with uniform standards, being sold anecdotal evidence that "diversity" is a strength etc.

The problem with test scores and neurosurgery is that there is no correlation between the surgeon's test score and his or her actual ability as a surgeon. I know this because I went to a very competitive medical school and saw some pretty smart people become pretty awful doctors. It seems that filling in little circles doesn't have much to do with medicine.

Those who believe that competition largely based on test scores will produce the best workers probably have not spent much time in academically competitive professions.

The pressure of taking standardized tests may weed out those who cannot endure pressure and stress. This may be a good thing because certain professions like the medical profession require high performance under pressure. Standardized tests are imperfect but we have nothing that can replace them. By the time you become a neurosurgeon you will have taken innumerable standardized tests under pressure and worked 80-hour work weeks under pressure as an intern or a resident. The selection process starts early and I see no substitute for competitive testing and competitive sports. Life is competition and attempts to deny this reality by advocating no test scores, no grades and sports events without scoring are doomed to fail.

We may play golf or play a violin to relax. Those who play golf for a living, PGA tour players, learn early how to compete under pressure. World class musicians earn recognition through a series of competitions. The same holds true for Olympic athletes. The pressure of competition is unavoidable be it at the grade school level or on the world stage.
